#Text=Joan Fitzgerald , Countess of Ormond
#Text=For other people named Joan Fitzgerald , see Joan Fitzgerald ( disambiguation ) .
#Text=Joan Fitzgerald , Countess of Ormond
#Text=, Countess of Desmond ( ca .
#Text=1509 or ca . 1514 – 2 January 1565 ) was an Irish noblewoman and heiress , a member of the Norman Fitzgerald family , who were also known as the " Geraldines " .
#Text=She married three times .

#Text=Her first husband was James Butler , 9th Earl of Ormond , who had been proposed as a bridegroom for Anne Boleyn in 1522 to settle a dispute over the title and estates of the Earldom of Ormond . [ 1 ]
#Text=Her second husband was courtier Sir Francis Bryan .

#Text=Her third marriage to Gerald FitzGerald , 15th Earl of Desmond brought peace to Ireland for a few years until he broke his truce with her eldest son Thomas Butler , 10th Earl of Ormond and warfare broke out between the rival Butler and Fitzgerald clans , who had been hereditary enemies for many generations .

#Text=Joan carried on an amicable correspondence with Queen Elizabeth I of England [ 2 ] who recognised Joan 's skill in diplomacy , and relied upon her to restore and keep the precarious peace in Munster . [ 3 ]
#Text=Family
#Text=Desmond Castle , Kinsale

#Text=Lady Joan was born in Desmond Castle , Kinsale , County Cork , Ireland in about 1509 [ 4 ] or 1514 , [ 5 ] the daughter and heiress-general of James FitzGerald , 10th Earl of Desmond and Amy O'Brien .
#Text=She had a younger sister , Lady Honora Fitzgerald ( died 1577 ) , who later married Pierce Butler .
#Text=Marriages and issue
#Text=Sometime before 21 December 1532 , she married her first husband James Butler , who succeeded as 9th Earl of Ormond on 26 August 1539 .

#Text=James had been proposed as a bridegroom to his cousin Anne Boleyn in 1522 in an attempt to settle a dispute over the title and estates of the earldom of Ormond to which Anne 's father , Sir Thomas Boleyn had a claim as his mother had been Lady Margaret Butler , eldest daughter of the 7th earl of Ormond .
#Text=For reasons unknown , the marriage negotiations came to a halt and Anne later became the second wife of King Henry VIII of England .
#Text=James and Joan had seven sons :
#Text=Thomas Butler , 10th Earl of Ormond
#Text=( c.1532- 22 November 1614 ) , married firstly Elizabeth Berkeley ; secondly , Elizabeth Sheffield , by whom he had issue ; thirdly , Helen Barry
#Text=John Butler of Kilcash
#Text=( died 10 May 1570 ) , married Katherine MacCartie , by whom he had a son , Walter Butler , 11th Earl of Ormond .
#Text=Edward Butler , married Mary Bourke , by whom he had issue .
#Text=Walter Butler , married and had one daughter .
#Text=Sir Edmund Butler
#Text=( 1534 – 1602 ) , married Eleanor Eustace , by whom he had issue .
#Text=James Butler of Duiske
#Text=Piers Butler
#Text=On 17 October 1546 , James went to dine at Ely House in Holborn , London .
#Text=He fell victim of a mass poisoning along with his steward and 16 of his servants . [ 6 ]
#Text=He died on 28 October , leaving Joan a widow in her thirties .
#Text=As a widow , she could legally act independently and she regained control of her dowry .
#Text=She sought the help of influential people at court to protect her children 's inheritance . [ 7 ]

#Text=She had desired to marry as her second husband her cousin Gerald FitzGerald , heir to the Earldom of Desmond and many years her junior ; however , she was forcefully persuaded to marry the English courtier and diplomat Sir Francis Bryan in August 1548 .
#Text=He was appointed Lord Chief Justice of Ireland and the couple returned to Ireland in November 1548 .
#Text=Due to his reputation of being a rake and libertine at the English court , Sir Francis Bryan earned the nickname " Vicar of Hell " .
#Text=Joan is quoted as saying , " While I was a widow and not married [ to ] an Englishman , I defended and kept my own , or at the least , no man went about to defeat me of my right .

#Text=She used her considerable talent for diplomacy to act as a  peacemaker " between her eldest son and third husband . [ 10 ]

column1: #Text=Faction fighting between the Butlers and Fitzgeralds

#Text=Joan maintained a friendly correspondence with Queen Elizabeth I , who recognised her ability , and relied on her to restore and keep the precarious peace in Munster after her husband , allegedly tired of Joan 's domination over him , [ 11 ] broke the truce with her eldest son , Thomas , who had succeeded his father as Earl of Ormond .

#Text=After the two factions began making raids against one another , Joan spent nearly two weeks journeying back and forth on horseback to arbitrate between the two enemy camps , before a tenuous peace was finally re-established . [ 12 ]
#Text=In 1562 , her husband was sent to the Tower of London for his allegedly " insolent " behaviour before the Privy Council .
#Text=Joan worked hard to persuade Queen Elizabeth to release him .
#Text=She was eventually successful in 1564 ; however , she herself died on 2 January 1565 .
#Text=She was buried at the Friary of Askeaton in Limerick .
#Text=Following her death , warfare broke out between the Butlers and Fitzgeralds , with her Butler son emerging the victor after the Battle of Affane in 1565 .
#Text=Joan , in her roles as landowner , household manager , and parent , wielded a powerful influence upon the lives of her tenants , retainers , and children . [ 13 ]
#Text=As a countess-albeit by marriage , she participated significantly in the world of Irish politics and the British royal Tudor court . [ 14 ]
